title-group.article-title: A product module identification approach based on axiomatic design and design structure matrix

abstract.p: In terms of creating customized products rapidly, modularity is deemed to be an effective developmental strategy for handling product variety and intricacy. In order to develop reasonable modular product architecture with physically detachable modules, a new systematic and structured approach for product modularization based on axiomatic design and design structure matrix is proposed. The product is decomposed hierarchically into its functional, physical, and process domains using axiomatic design method. After transformation from design matrix to design structure matrix, the pertinence design structure matrices of design parameters describing function, structure, and manufacturing process are constructed. Besides, a manufacturing process similarity matrix of design parameters is established. Finally, a genetic algorithm combined with the minimal description length is employed to realize the modularization optimization after integration of the above matrices. To illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed methodology, an indoor air conditioner unit is presented as a demonstrative example.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In order to respond rapidly to the concurrent demands of increasing product variety and reducing manufacturing costs, it is necessary to handle these intricacies by splitting a product into smaller controllable units, allowing companies to maximize control of the product and product-related activities (Ericsson and Erixon, 1999). Modular architecture symbolizes a one-to-one mapping of performance elements to physical building blocks with distinct interfaces (Ulrich and Eppinger, 2004), and is justly considered a promising solution to this design efficiency problem.

In order to manage modular configurations, Ulrich and Eppinger (2004), Otto and Wood (2001), and Baldwin and Clark (2000) have defined different categories of modularity. Many researches on modularity originate from Suh’s (1990) independence axiom. Huang and Kusiak (1996) defined product modularity as the creation of product variants out of common units. Ulrich and Eppinger (2004) presented their view of modularity as being based on two characteristics of design: (1) the relationship between the physical and functional architecture of the design and (2) the minimization of incidental interactions between the physical components. Furthermore, Gershenson et al. (2003) defined modularity as having three fundamental elements: (1) the independence of a module’s components from external components, (2) the similarity of components in a module with respect to their life-cycle processes, and (3) the absence of similarities to external components. Modular architecture is traditionally made up of functionally independent clusters of components. However, the manufacturing efficiency of the modules may deteriorate if the relative structural information is not considered in the module identification process. Physical interactions derived from manufacturability should also be a major concern of physical modularity (Jiao et al., 2007), and modules may be created with some aspects of production in mind. In addition to pertinence, there is pressure to look at the similarity or compatibility within modules. In addition, modularization is not only beneficial to the improvement of the cost–variety tradeoff in product development, but can also offer valuable guidelines for fundamental improvement redesign.

To achieve these goals, this article presents an approach to module identification based on axiomatic design (AD) theory and design structure matrix (DSM). The rest of the article proceeds as follows. Section “Literature survey of existing modularization methods” presents a brief survey of the different existing modularization methods in product design. In “The framework of the proposed approach” section, the framework of the proposed approach is provided. The four sections that follow introduce the proposed approach in four main steps. “An illustrative modularization example” section illustrates the module identification process with a case study. The final section provides discussions and conclusions.

sec.title: Literature survey of existing modularization methods
sec.p: A number of methodologies and theories on modularization address the identification and formation process of modules under definite conditions (Gershenson et al., 2003; Jiao et al., 2007). According to the viewpoint under consideration, current approaches for module planning and identification can be classified into several categories.

Pahl and Beitz (1984) paved the way for the modularization according to functionality and used a functional structure diagram to cluster components. Based on this research, Stone et al. (2000) proposed a function structure heuristic method for identifying modules from the functional model of products. With the definition of a fractal as an independent module with precisely defined functionality, Kahmeyer et al. (1994) proposed a fractal product design method. Physical structure–based approaches are focused on the structural elements of a product and their relationships, and Pimmler and Eppinger (1994) provided a typical research with consideration of spatial energy, information, and material interactions.

However, a module should be comprehensively defined with factors of both the functional and physical architecture in mind according to the modularity viewed by Ulrich and Eppinger (2004). Hence, Salhieh and Kamrani (1999) and Krenga and Lee (2004) proposed methods to accomplish modular product design according to its functional and physical characteristics. Because AD inherently assures good modularity based on the process of decomposition and the development of uncoupled or decoupled designs (Kim et al., 1991), Tseng and Jiao (1997), Tate et al. (1998), and Holmqvist and Persson (2003) have discussed AD as a modularization method.

Moreover, some researchers (Lee, 1994) also discussed the manufacturing-based methods in order to face new challenges due to the increasingly complicated assembly and subassembly. In general, these methods do not cover the algorithm for the product modules formation. Emphasis is often placed on smooth connections between the design and manufacturing phases (Tseng et al., 2008). In this domain, Huang and Kusiak (1996) measured the performance of product designs by manufacturing time and formulated the modular design as an integer-programming problem. Kahoo and Situmdrang (2003) proposed an approach based on the principles of natural immune systems to solve the design of an assembly system for modular products.

In order to incorporate the potential of modularity based not only on the form/function structure of a product, but also on life-cycle processes such as manufacturing, assembly, service, and recycling, Gershenson et al. (1999) proposed a definition for product life-cycle modularity. Gu and Sosale (1999) presented an innovative approach to modular design by considering product life-cycle engineering at the design stage. Sand et al. (2002), Kusiak (2002), Newcomb et al. (1998), and Smith and Yen (2010) proposed methodologies that brought forward a modular design with product life-cycle objectives. A number of other researchers (Seliger and Zettl, 2008; Umeda et al., 2009; Erixon and Ostgren, 1993) have used various life-cycle aspects such as recycling, maintenance, reuse, upgrading, and sales scenarios to propose modular design approaches.

sec.title: The framework of the proposed approach
sec.p: In order to accomplish the decomposition, characterization, and clustering process systematically and comprehensively, a new modularization method is presented in this research based on AD and DSM. To decompose concurrently, the zigzagging mapping among the functional, physical, and process domains in AD is introduced. To characterize the interrelation between design parameters (DPs) more visually, DSM is derived from design matrix (DM) in AD. To cluster module more reasonably, genetic algorithm (GA) with minimal description length (MDL) is adopted. The overall procedure of the proposed approach is illustrated in Figure 1. The framework includes four main steps. Step 1 is to obtain the overall pertinence DSM of DPs, which assembles the three aspects of pertinence relationship of functionality, structure, and manufacturing process. Step 2 is to construct the similarity DSM of DPs from manufacturing process. Based on the above two steps, Step 3 is to aggregate the overall pertinence DSM with similarity DSM and obtain the overall interrelation DSM of DPs. Step 4 is to cluster the overall interrelation DSM and achieve modules with the help of GA and MDL.

sec.title: Obtain DSM from DM
sec.p: Although AD with a DM can perfectly depict the corresponding relationships between domains, it falls short of describing the interaction phenomenon between elements in an individual domain. However, DSM is a powerful information exchange model that provides an elegant representation of the interactions that exist between the elements of a decomposed system or product (Tang et al., 2010). Therefore, it is a good idea to convert the DM to DSM to capture the interaction among elements in a system and the reasons for those interactions.

FRs play the role of design objectives that are satisfied with the corresponding hierarchical structure of DPs in the physical domain. The DPs in question are achieved through the proper selection of process variables (PVs) in the process domain. As for product development, the PVs can be interpreted as the manufacturing process design (Houshmand and Jamshidnezhad, 2006).

sec.title: Establish pertinence DSM of DPs based on manufacturing process
sec.p: As noted earlier, the relationship between the physical and process domains is similar to that between the functional and physical domains, so DSMPV of the DPs driven by PVs can be obtained in the similar way.

sec.title: Establish pertinence DSM of DPs based on structure
sec.p: In addition to the pertinence relationships from the perspectives of functionality and manufacturing process represented by DSMFR and DSMPV, there is also structural pertinence that reflects the correlative degree between DPs from a structural perspective. In this article, the structural pertinence of DPs is considered to consist of physical and geometrical pertinences. The composing relationship of physical pertinence indicates that there are energy, information, or material flows and other physical relationships between DPs. Energy flows refer to the transferred driving force, torque, power, electrical current, or liquid pressure between DPs. Information flows are the transfer of information or signals. Material flows describe the transfer of material, parts, fixtures, or cutting tools between DPs. Geometrical pertinence means that there are connecting, fastening, dimensioning, parallelism, verticality, coaxiality, and other association relationships. sec.title: Establish manufacturing process similarity DSM of DPs: Step 2
sec.p: Each product module’s configurability, alterability, and manufacturing efficiency should be considered simultaneously during module identification (Meng, 2007). Gershenson et al. (1999) gave a definition of process similarity where group components and subassemblies that undergo the same or compatible life-cycle processes into the same module. Process similarity minimizes the number of external components that are subjected to the same processes, creates a strong differentiation between modules, and reduces process repetition and process costs (Lai and Gershenson, 2007).

The manufacturing process of a module is the summation of all the processes of the components, or parts in it. Suppose the pertinence value of the DPs and the process route is P(i,j), i∈I,j∈J, where I is the set of DPs of the product, and J is the set of processes. Each element in the matrix can be designated with a Boolean value of 0 or 1, in order to indicate whether the corresponding DP passes by the process link. Thus, a process route of each DP can be established.

sec.p: Thus far, the pertinence DSM and the manufacturing process similarity DSM of DPs have been obtained. Assuming a product can be decomposed into n DPs, then their DSMs of pertinence and similarity are both n×n matrices. As for the modularization process, it aims for identification of modules with maximum pertinence and similarity relations within them. Higher values of τ indicate a greater willingness to allow a high preference for one criterion to compensate for lower values of another. αper and αsim are the pertinence and similarity values, respectively, to be clustered.
Thus, we can get the overall interrelation DSM of a product’s DPs, which comprehensively reflects the interaction relationship between the DPs.

sec.title: Identify module based on GA and MDL: Step 4
sec.p: To perform the clustering, GA based on the principles of evolution observed in nature (Goldberg, 1989) is used in this study. MDL principle (Lutz, 2002) is selected as the objective function of the GA to minimize the value for the clustering criterion. The MDL can be interpreted as follows: among all possible models, choose the model that uses the minimal length for describing a given data set (i.e. the model description length plus the mismatched data description length) (Yu et al., 2007). The MDL-GA has been validated as capable of solving complex clustering problems that include overlapping clusters, a bus, and a 3D structure (Yu et al., 2007).

(2007). nn is the element number in the DSM, nc is the number of clusters set for the DSM, and cli is the number of nodes in the ith cluster. If elements are fallen into module when they have no relationship, this mismatch is termed S1. sec.p: A wall-mounted split air conditioner is a product that comes in many varieties, where the changes occur mainly in shape, size, and capacity. sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As a result of the functional and structural pertinence relationship that reflects the customer requirements and structure conjunction, the DPs DP111, DP112, DP113, DP121, DP122, DP123, DP131, and DP132 compose heat exchange module. Due to the structural and manufacturing process pertinence existing between DP2141 and DP2142, and the manufacturing process similarity between DP2141, DP2142, DP22, DP23, DP41, and DP42, the DPs DP2111, DP2112, DP212, DP213, DP2141, DP2142, DP2151, DP2152, DP22, DP23, DP41, and DP42 are optimized and organized as a packaging and drainage module. Owing to the functional and structural pertinence relationship, DP311, DP312, DP321, DP322, DP323, DP324, DP325, and DP326 make up the ventilation module, and DP51, DP52, DP53, and DP54 constitute the control module. Similarly, as the DPs DP61 and DP62 have both manufacturing process pertinence and similarity, besides functional correlation, they are grouped into one module called the power module. From the whole illustration process, because the DPs in each resultant module are relatively centralized, it is can be seen that AD theory can provide better consistency during the decomposition in functional, physical, and process domains with zigzagging mapping. And this establishes the soundness of that AD theory can assure good modularity inherently.

The modularization process of the air conditioner illustration can certainly be executed by other methods with considerations of functionality relation, physical relation, or manufacturing process relation. Taking the methods with physical relation as an example for comparison and as they only consider the physical interaction between DPs, the functionality and manufacturing process relations cannot be taken into account during the modularization. Therefore, even though DP41, DP42, DP2141, DP2142, DP22, and DP23 have manufacturing process similarity because they are self-manufactured with similar injection mold, they cannot be clustered into one module because there is no physical relation between them. Similarly, taking the methods with manufacturing process relation as an example for comparison, according to their partition rules, DP111, DP2111, DP213, DP2141, DP2142, DP22, DP23, DP323, DP324, DP325, DP41, and DP42 should be clustered into one module because they are self-manufactured with similar injection mold. But because of their weak relation with functional and physical relation, they cannot be clustered together. Accordingly, the methods based on physical relation or those based on manufacturing process deduce modularization results unilaterally. Thus, it can be concluded that because the proposed method comprehensively considers the pertinence relation coming from functional, physical, manufacturing process domains, and the similarity relation coming from manufacturing process domain, the modularization results are more reasonable. With different executants in different companies with various considerations and emphases during the implementation process, different product module schemes will be obtained.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Methods and tools are needed to facilitate the decision-making and management of modularization in the manufacturing industry as module configurability, module alterability, and module manufacturing efficiency need to be considered simultaneously during the process. A modularization method based on AD and DSM through comprehensive consideration of FRs, physical structure, and manufacturing processes is proposed in this article. Characteristics of this modularization identification method are summarized as follows:

list-item.p: With the four design domains of AD as the primary line of analysis, the pertinence relation of DPs are taken into account, not only including those from functional domains and physical domains that are usually considered in traditional methods, but also those from the process domain. Compared with the traditional method, the method based on AD is more comprehensive and systematic.

The similarity of the DPs is also considered during the modularization process guided by the proposed method, so the DPs or parts in a module can have as similar manufacturing processes as possible. During the manufacturing process, the components can be organized with reference to their manufacturing process, and can reduce the repetition of the manufacturing process and cost.
With DSM transformed by DM as the main analysis tool, the whole module identification process is implemented visually and concisely and is also convenient to be carried out with the computer.

sec.p: Despite the progress, a number of issues need to be further addressed to improve the currently developed method. Our future research will focus on the following two aspects: (1) Determination of the hierarchical level of decomposition between the functional, physical, and process domains with the AD method. (2) Establishment of an effective method to evaluate the modularization results, as the extent to which the product is modularized significantly influences the benefit to a company. (3) Consideration of the remanufacturing requirements in advance to enhance the remanufacturing ability and sustainability of modules.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Qiang Cheng is an instructor and supervisor for M.S. students in the College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, China. He graduated from Huazhong University of Science & Technology with a Ph.D. in Industrial Engineering. His research interests include adaptable design, modular design, and accuracy design of machine tool, etc.

Guojun Zhang is a professor in State Key Lab of Digital Manufacturing Equipment and Technology, Huazhong University of Science & Technology, China. Professor Zhang is the Director of Manufacturing Equipment Digitalization of Guangdong Province. His research interests include modern design methods, digital equipment and manufacturing execution system, etc.

Peihua Gu is a Professor and Vice-President (Academic) in the Department of Mechatronics Engineering, Shantou University and Changjiang Scholar Chair Professor at Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China. Prior to the appointment at Shantou University, Professor Gu was Head of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering and holder of NSERC Chair in Life Cycle Design Engineering at University of Calgary. He is Fellow of the Canadian Academy of Engineering and International Academy of Production Engineering (CIRP). His research interests include adaptable design, robust design, and CAD/CAM.

Xinyu Shao is a professor in Huazhong University of Science and Technology. From 1995 to 1998, Shao studied in the University of Michigan (U.S.A.) as a PhD candidate and worked in Ford Motor Company as a research associate. He has been working in Huazhong University of Science and Technology (China) since 1998 and now is the vice-president of this university. His research interests include CAD/CAPP/PDM/ERP, CIMS, Concurrent Engineering and Agile Manufacturing, etc.
